Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Star Formation in Subcritical Environments
Award.AbstractNarration:
AST-0707563/0707426/0707468/0707835
Hunter/Elmegreen/Simpson/Young

This is a collaborative project led by Dr Deidre Hunter of Lowell Observatory, along with Dr Bruce Elmegreen at the IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Dr Caroline Simpson of Florida International University, and Dr Lisa Young from the New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology.

The team will obtain and analyze high angular and velocity resolution neutral hydrogen interferometric data of dwarf irregular galaxies and combine these with their extensive optical, ultra-violet, and infra-red images, in order to determine how these galaxies form star-forming gas clouds that propel their evolution. This study will lead to an improved understanding of star formation in all disk galaxies, by addressing a number of questions: what regulates star formation in small galaxies; what is the relative importance of sequential triggering; what regulates turbulence; how important is triggering by random turbulence; what is happening in the far outer parts of dwarf galaxies; what aspect of star formation changes in blue compact dwarf galaxies? These questions need to be answered because dwarf galaxies are the most common galaxy, the most pristine chemically, and the type most closely connected to the earliest star-forming systems in the universe.

High school students, undergraduates, graduate students, and post-doctoral researchers have been, and will continue to be, involved in this journey of scientific discovery. Many of these participants have in the past been women, and some were also from under-represented groups. The team will continue this preference. The investigators are all also involved in continuing public and K-12 outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
“Star Formation in Sub-Critical Environments” was a five year program to observe and analyze interstellar gas in small local galaxies that span a wide range of star formation activities. The primary reason for choosing these galaxies is that they resemble young galaxies in the early universe that are much more difficult to observe. Both types have high ratios of gas mass to stellar mass, low ratios of carbon, oxygen and other heavy elements compared to hydrogen, and clumpy, thick morphologies. Starting with optical and infrared data on 140 galaxies, we observed interstellar hydrogen in 21 of them with unprecedented clarity using the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array in New Mexico, and we made new maps of hydrogen in an additional 20 from archival data. We also observed several of the galaxies at millimeter wavelengths using the Atacama Pathfinder EXperiment telescope in Chile. Among the most important results was the discovery of peripheral streams of extragalactic gas impacting or getting flung out from several of the highest star-forming cases, and the realization that the largest star-forming clumps are so massive and long-lasting that they will circle into the central regions to feed even greater star formation activity in the near future. These processes almost certainly accompanied the youngest galaxies also as they formed in the early universe. We also observed very old and regular structures in the far outer parts of several local galaxies, suggesting a long history of stellar migration and peripheral star formation by unknown processes. Most likely the youngest galaxies did not have these outer structures soon after they formed, and the processes that made them are still evident but not yet recognized in galaxies today. Further supporting our understanding of the youngest galaxies, we detected molecular clouds for the first time in a galaxy with relative oxygen abundance lower than that of our near neighbor, the Small Magellanic Cloud. All star formation occurs in molecular clouds like these, making their observation crucial in both local and high redshift galaxies that are too young or inactive to have formed much oxygen yet.
